text: love the sous-chef John from food wishes
comm with fried peach and pancetta pizza
that's right we're doing fried pizza
which I was gonna call Frieza but then I
was afraid people would think that meant
fruit pizza and there would have been
massive confusion so we're not going to
do that and believe it or not this was
inspired by a childhood dessert because
my family used to take leftover pizza
dough scraps and they'd fry it and toss
it and sugar to make like a quick donut
like treat but here we're going to take
that same idea and turn it into a savory
application so I'm gonna go ahead and
get started by cooking some pancetta so
in a cold skillet I have a big handful
of some thickly sliced pancetta and I'm
going to add a little drizzle of olive
oil to get things started and we'll go
ahead and put that on medium heat and
cook it until we have something very
nicely caramelized and all pancetta is a
cured pork they call it italian bacon
but it is a smoked so the flavor is not
really bacon like but just absolutely
delicious nonetheless and like I said
we're going to cook that until it's
fairly well caramelized so here we're
starting to get there so I let this go a
couple more minutes until I had
something that resembled this at that
point all I want you to do is turn off
the heat and let that cool right in the
pan because when we use this to top our
pizzas we do want a little bit of that
oil coming along for the ride okay so
we'll turn off the heat we'll leave that
right there and we'll move on to the
pizza dough so yes you're going to need
some prepared pizza dough and I'm going
to cut that in quarters because I'm
going to make little small pizzas and
we'll take one of those pieces and we'll
dust it with flour and as with anything
like this we just want to use enough
flour so we can work with it don't put
too much flour all right don't be afraid

want to do is roll this out and/or
stretch it with our hands to get it
about 1/8 of an inch thick so I kind of
use a combination of pulling and

to be perfect except for a perfect

that imperfect shape is one of the

we're going to roll that out to about an
eighth of an inch thick and when it gets
to this point I kind of like to finish
off by just stretching it with my
fingertips there should be just enough
stickiness to kind of make it here and
sort of keep it stretched out like that
so that looks good at that point just
let it sit there and rest for about five
minutes before we go ahead and fry this
in olive oil somebody
heavy cast-iron skillet set on
medium-high heat and we're just going to

inch of olive oil in there and we'll
carefully place that dough in protip
don't burn yourself always place it in a
way that if it splashes it splashes away

about two minutes per side or until it's
nicely browned and cooked through and
you're going to see both sides you can
have a very distinctive look so I'm
going to flip this over and the side
that went down first is going to be
quite browned around the outside around
the outside around the outside but the

don't worry that's where our toppings
are going to go so that will be the top
and then this other side is you'll see
is going to pretty much brown across the
whole surface so that looks good and
like I said it's going to take about 2
minutes per side give or take but you'll
know because it'll look like this and
then what we'll do is we'll drain that
very well on paper towels at that point
your fried pizza dough is ready for
toppings and one cool thing about this
is you can do this step ahead even the

this head I want to eat right now so I'm
going to go ahead and transfer those
onto a foil lined baking sheet again we

don't put too much but make sure you got

you may see a little bit of
